formatted-caption.caption-text: Field Development Project Area, Offshore Indonesia

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Installation Stages for Cased Hole Frac-Packs and Intelligent Well Systems

formatted-caption.caption-text: Installation Stages for Cased Hole Frac-Packs and Intelligent Well Systems

linkTarget.anchoringText: Deposition is fluvial/deltaic with almost all sands being weakly consolidated to unconsolidated and therefore requiring downhole sand exclusion completions. The sands are thin and have small grain sizes with typical D50 values in the 40 to 140 micron range. Gas permeabilities are good with core measured permeabilities in the 10 to 10,000 md range and flow test measured zone-average permeability values in the 10 md to several thousand md range. As indicated in Figure 3, below, the sands are thin and spread over long gross intervals providing low net-to-gross ratios averaging less than 30%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Geological Cross-Section Showing Sand/Shale Sequence for Example Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geological Cross-Section Showing Sand/Shale Sequence for Example Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 4, below, illustrates key components of the Single-Trip Multi-Zone Gravel Pack system used. Additional details on the Single-Trip Multi-Zone Gravel Pack system can be found in the paper by Zhou et al, 2014.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Single-Trip Multi-Zone Gravel Pack System Installed in Example Well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Single-Trip Multi-Zone Gravel Pack System Installed in Example Well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 5, below, provides an illustration of key components of the IWS Completion String

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: IWS String Installed Inside of Single-Trip Multi-Zone Gravel Pack System

formatted-caption.caption-text: IWS String Installed Inside of Single-Trip Multi-Zone Gravel Pack System

linkTarget.anchoringText: While the 3-1/2” production inner string and 2-7/8” interval control valves were considered small for low pressure gas flow, frictional pressure losses were considered acceptable in terms of long term well flow performance. Maximum single zone rates were expected be around 25 MMSCFD with total well rates in the 65MMSCFDrange as shown in Figure 6, below

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: IPR Prediction for Well-1 Showing Flow Potential of All Six Zones When Commingled

formatted-caption.caption-text: IPR Prediction for Well-1 Showing Flow Potential of All Six Zones When Commingled

linkTarget.anchoringText: The solution was to manufacture the flat-packs with a trapezoidal shape, curved to closely match the diameter of the IWS Production Tubing. The curved trapezoidal shape shown in Figure 7 above, created a smooth profile which eliminated square edges and thereby allowed the BOP’s Annular element to provide an effective seal. The new flat-pack design was successfully tested by repeatedly opening and closing the Test BOP Annular on the 4-1/2” production tubing with an 8-line flat-pack.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Flat-Pack Hydraulic and Electric Control Line Configuration for 6-Zone IWS

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flat-Pack Hydraulic and Electric Control Line Configuration for 6-Zone IWS

linkTarget.anchoringText: Zonal multi-rate tests were repeated after approximately six to eight months of flow to see if skin values had improved further or had deteriorated. Results of the second series of multi-rate tests showed no significant increases or decreases in skin. This is shown in Figure 15, below

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of Skin Results After Initial Rig Flow, After 2 Months Production and After 6 Months of Stabilized Production Flow

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of Skin Results After Initial Rig Flow, After 2 Months Production and After 6 Months of Stabilized Production Flow

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Correlation of Zone-Specific Skin Results with Zonal Reservoir Permeability

formatted-caption.caption-text: Correlation of Zone-Specific Skin Results with Zonal Reservoir Permeability

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of Multi-Rate Test Data with Kpt/Kr Skin Match

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of Multi-Rate Test Data with Kpt/Kr Skin Match

linkTarget.anchoringText: As expected, several zones have had to be shut-in due to high water production rates which jeopardized recovery from offsetting zones. An early example of the production benefit of having an IWS system capable of shutting in high-rate water production can be seen in Figure 19, below

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Well Data Showing Gas and Water Rates Before and After Shutting-In Water Zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well Data Showing Gas and Water Rates Before and After Shutting-In Water Zone
